title: Corrections: May 30, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 30, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about the activation of the National Guard amid protests in Minneapolis referred incorrectly to Kirsten Delegard’s employer. She works for the Mapping Prejudice project at the University of Minnesota, but she is not a professor there or at Augsburg University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Andrew J. Ries brings some order to this mixed-up, crazy world, or vice versa.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Not bragging, but explaining the last few puzzles by Andrew J. Reis has taught me a lot, and I am finding myself increasingly prepared for his new puzzles. There are a few stumpers today, but if you’re getting to the point where you know your containers from your charades and your homophones, you might feel the same way about a clever little jewel box like this P and A. If not, then grab a guide and keep reading for hints — you’ll get there soon!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and Nicholas Fandos
title: Flynn Discussed Sanctions at Length With Russian Diplomat, Transcripts Show
description: The former national security adviser now says he does not remember those discussions as he fights a criminal charge he had previously pleaded guilty to.
content: WASHINGTON — The former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn discussed sanctions at length with a Russian diplomat in late 2016, according to transcripts declassified on Friday that appear to bolster earlier assertions that Mr. Flynn misled Vice President Mike Pence and F.B.I. agents about those conversations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: What Goes UpMust Come Down
description: Lewis Rothlein and Jeff Chen raise us high and drop us low.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — After a couple of trippy weeks we have a classic today, a grid that finds a wild little feature in the language, one we’ve all seen before but might not have noticed, and expands on it to make a polished Sunday puzzle. Jeff Chen is involved, and Lewis Rothlein makes his Sunday debut after a run of five Thursdays, so we know we have some theme veterans at work (Will Shortz’s introduction says the two constructors exchanged over 100 emails on the theme alone).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: Here’s What You Need to Know About Breonna Taylor’s Death
description: Fury over the killing of Ms. Taylor by the police has been growing, driving tense demonstrations in Louisville, Ky., and elsewhere.
content: While the death this week of George Floyd in Minneapolis has unleashed a wave of protests across the country, fury over the killing of an African-American medical worker in Louisville, Ky., by the police has also been growing, driving tense demonstrations in that city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: The Latest From Minneapolis
description: In the wake of George Floyd’s death, a city is ablaze in a longstanding demand for justice.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Postpones June G7 Summit
description: The German chancellor had announced earlier Saturday that she would not travel to the U.S. for the G7. Businesses are starting up again, but workers commuting by public transportation face dilemmas.
content: This live briefing has ended. Click here for the latest global updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Think Outside the Box, Jack
description: Trump, Twitter and the society-crushing pursuit of monetized rage.
content: WASHINGTON — C’mon, @Jack. You can do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Case Against Riots
description: What nonviolent protest gains, violent protest unravels.
content: In the origin myth of post-1960s liberalism, all the defeats that the Democratic Party suffered in the years of Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan were owed to the party’s heroic support for civil rights, which rectified a great injustice but opened the way for the Republicans to build majorities on racial backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Paul
title: In Case of Emergency, Make Art
description: Hand a kid colored pencils and the trepidation and confusion of the coronavirus pandemic transmutes into striped penguins.
content: I was a firefighter for many years. But because it was more than a decade ago, it often seems like another person wore those turnout boots, cinched that ax belt and ran into burning buildings. Yet when the Covid-19 pandemic hit a few months ago, my old first-responder instincts rose up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip V. McHarris and Thenjiwe McHarris
title: No More Money for the Police
description: Redirect it to emergency response programs that don’t kill black people.
content: The only way we’re going to stop these endless cycles of police violence is by creating alternatives to policing. Because even in a pandemic where black people have been disproportionately killed by the coronavirus, the police are still murdering us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Remember, No One Is Coming to Save Us
description: Eventually doctors will find a coronavirus vaccine, but black people will continue to wait for a cure for racism.
content: After Donald Trump maligned the developing world in 2018, with the dismissive phrase “shithole countries,” I wrote that no one was coming to save us from the president. Now, in the midst of a pandemic, we see exactly what that means.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Lifts NASA Astronauts to Orbit, Launching New Era of Spaceflight
description: The trip to the space station was the first from American soil since 2011 when the space shuttles were retired.
content: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — The United States opened a new era of human space travel on Saturday as a private company for the first time launched astronauts into orbit, nearly a decade after the government retired the storied space shuttle program in the aftermath of national tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How We Broke the World
description: Greed and globalization set us up for disaster.
content: If recent weeks have shown us anything, it’s that the world is not just flat. It’s fragile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How to Get Your Money to Those Who Need It More Than You
description: Your instinct may be to help right now, in cash. These services bridge the gap between Venmoing someone from Twitter and a check to a big charity that could steer that money anywhere.
content: As unemployment claims pass 40 million and the anxious people who file them grow more desperate, an altruistic instinct has emerged among those who are more financially secure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Kris Kobach Is Back, and a Kansas Senate Seat May Be Up for Grabs
description: Mr. Kobach’s polarizing presence in a race in a reliably Republican stronghold has party leaders worried that Kansas will become a high-stakes battleground for control of the Senate.
content: LEAWOOD, Kan. — It has been 88 years since Kansas last sent a Democrat to the United States Senate — one of only three Democrats ever to represent the state in the upper chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Ramy’ and ‘The High Note’
description: Ramy Youssef’s faith-focused dramedy is back for a second season, and a comedy about the music industry arrives on digital platforms.
content: RAMY Stream on Hulu. This dramedy series made a splash when it debuted last year for putting the experiences of American Muslims front and center. Created by the comedian Ramy Youssef, who also stars as the title character, the show follows an Egyptian-American millennial in New Jersey torn by hedonistic pleasures and his desire to reconnect with his faith. Existential questions are still swirling through Ramy’s mind in Season 2, but he’s now unpacking them with help of a spiritual mentor (newcomer Mahershala Ali). We learn more about Ramy’s family and watch as he navigates sticky situations that test his faith. In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, Youssef suggested that this season may spark “uncomfortable conversations” among critical viewers — for one, the trailer reveals a scene featuring a former adult film star — but it also offers a more intimate look at his character’s spiritual motivations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Coronavirus Slams Broken, Embattled Yemen
description: Lacking equipment, expertise and authority, a divided, war-torn country bobbles a response to a surging pandemic.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In northern Yemen, more and more people are falling ill and dying after having trouble breathing, yet the Iran-backed group that controls the region, the Houthis, has acknowledged only a few coronavirus deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leonard S. Marcus
title: For Fans of Ivan, the Answer to ‘What About Bob?’
description: In Katherine Applegate’s “The One and Only Bob,” Ivan’s best buddy strikes out on his own.
content: Outsider stories resonate strongly with children: Even the luckiest of us start life in a land of giants where doorknobs and cookie jars hover beyond reach and adults call most of the shots. Katherine Applegate has made a specialty of mining this emotional territory in novels that blend elements of fantasy and realism while tracking the changing fortunes of resilient outsiders — like a homeless fifth grader (“Crenshaw”) and a Sudanese refugee (“Home of the Brave”), or, most memorably to date, a silverback gorilla living in captivity as the star attraction of a squalid shopping-mall tourist destination (“The One and Only Ivan”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: What Is Your Most Significant Relationship? Here Are 10 Answers
description: As they deal with the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, people across the United States reflect on their most treasured personal relationships with family, friends, partners and pets.
content: In times of celebration, growth and uncertainty, the most significant people in our lives extend companionship and support. Sometimes by chance, important bonds are forged instantly over an unplanned event. In other instances, ties develop gradually throughout years of shared experiences. Here’s what 10 people had to say about their connections with their family, friends, partners and even pets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Zach Montague
title: Past Presidents Faced Police Brutality and Protests. They Handled It Differently.
description: President Trump’s predecessors took different approaches when responding — or not responding — to police killings or assaults of black men. But they never threatened violence against protesters.
content: It is a bleak reality of American history that each of the past four presidents faced the same crisis President Trump is facing now: The police just killed or seriously injured a black man, and the city where it happened is reeling with grief and rage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Top U.S. Coronavirus Hot Spots Are All Indian Lands
description: Living conditions make it difficult to contain the virus's spread.
content: CHINLE, Ariz. — The Navajo Nation is a vast, awe-inspiring land of desert crags and canyons, the largest reservation in the country, but today it reverberates with grief and fear.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lessons for the Future From Online Learning
description: Should schools incorporate more virtual learning when they reopen? Students and educators respond to one student’s enthusiasm for it.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carson Ellis
title: Draw a Self-Portrait
description: Our template provides guidelines on spacing, now you just have to really look. And don’t move!
content: There is truly no time like the present to give drawing a shot, and a self-portrait is an excellent place to start. The template  provided here can help you figure out how to draw a human face — how much space there is between all of its parts and what goes where.  Some of the best portraits in the world don’t follow these rules and you don’t always have to either, but it’s helpful to know them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court, in 5-4 Decision, Rejects Church’s Challenge to Shutdown Order
description: A California church argued that restrictions on public gatherings treated houses of worship worse than many businesses.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday turned away a request from a church in California to block enforcement of state restrictions on attendance at religious services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Days of Discord, a President Fans the Flames
description: Mr. Trump has presented himself as someone who seeks conflict, not conciliation, a fighter, not a peacemaker. And he has lived up to his self-image at a perilous time.
content: WASHINGTON — With a nation on edge, ravaged by disease, hammered by economic collapse, divided over lockdowns and even face masks and now convulsed once again by race, President Trump’s first instinct has been to look for someone to fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Stewart
title: The White Dog Walker and #LivingWhileBlack in New York City
description: The confrontation between a black bird watcher and a white woman walking her dog reminded many black residents that a diverse city can also be hostile.
content: Samuel Roberts, a professor at Columbia University, remembered being stopped by the police as he walked his Rottweiler along Morningside Drive after someone reported that a black man was robbing people with a dog in tow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: ‘They’re Just Doing Whatever They Want’: Few Masks Are Seen as Beach Town Reopens
description: As businesses in the Maryland town of Ocean City try to enforce mask wearing, they are finding some visitors unwilling to comply.
content: OCEAN CITY, Md. — Dave Heyburn and Nevada Kaler viewed their weekend on this seaside boardwalk as an escape from the coronavirus “red zone” where they live, in Elverson, Pa. Neither wore masks, which are not required to be worn outdoors here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Tiffany May, Austin Ramzy and Lam Yik Fei
title: ‘Facing the Darkest Hour’: Hong Kong’s Protest Movement in Crisis
description: As the Chinese government’s grip tightens, protesters are debating how and why to keep fighting, or whether resistance is even possible.
content: HONG KONG — Protesters have deleted their social media accounts, afraid that their messages could be used against them under China’s new national security laws. Young parents have scoured the internet for instructions on emigration. Organizers have planned rallies, only to cancel them at the last minute in the face of impenetrable police blockades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Campbell Robertson
title: ‘Wow, Everything’s Gone’: The Covid Class of 2020
description: Born in the wake of 9/11, they entered adulthood in the middle of a global pandemic. Meet a generation bookended by tragedy.
content: Born in the wake of 9/11, they entered adulthood in the middle of a global pandemic. Meet a generation bookended by tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: John Loengard, Life Photographer and Chronicler, Dies at 85
description: He shot compelling portraits of the Beatles, Georgia O’Keeffe and many others. He also celebrated photography, and Life magazine, in several books.
content: When Life magazine sent John Loengard to Miami to photograph the Beatles in February 1964, he had a quirky idea: Pose them in a swimming pool, as a Fab Four of bobbing heads. But on a very chilly day, he could find only an unheated pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Campbell Robertson
title: ‘Wow, Everything’s Gone’: The Covid Class of 2020
description: Born in the wake of 9/11, they entered adulthood in the middle of a global pandemic. Meet a generation bookended by tragedy.
content: Born in the wake of 9/11, they entered adulthood in the middle of a global pandemic. Meet a generation bookended by tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fiery Clashes Between Police and Protesters
description: Standoffs intensified across the country on Saturday, as officials in Minneapolis vowed to take a harder line against unrest in the streets.
content: Protesters who took to the streets in Minneapolis for the fifth straight night on Saturday met a more determined response from police officers and National Guard troops, as demonstrations escalated in dozens of cities across the country — an outpouring of national anger sparked by the death of a black man in police custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Thousands of Complaints Do Little to Change Police Ways
description: Efforts to hold problem officers accountable face resistance from unions, and juries are reluctant to second-guess.
content: In nearly two decades with the Minneapolis Police Department, Derek Chauvin faced at least 17 misconduct complaints, none of which derailed his career.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Problem With Military Base Names
description: Readers say those named for Confederate Army officers should be changed; another points to the overriding fact that the U.S. military was a pioneer in achieving racial equality.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Michael Levenson
title: Atlanta Protesters Clash With Police as Mayor Warns ‘You Are Disgracing Our City’
description: Protesters broke windows and set fire to cars after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Protests emerged in many U.S. cities.
content: ATLANTA — Hundreds of demonstrators poured into the streets near Atlanta’s Centennial Olympic Park on Friday night, smashing windows and clashing with police officers in a protest that grew so tense that the city’s mayor forcefully told people to go home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Handy
title: A Tale of Twinned Cities
description: In William Shivering’s “Thieves of Weirdwood,” a mirror city’s buildings and streets physically reflect the hopes and fears of a “normal,” grim, Dickensian city’s residents.
content: The most important thing to know about William Shivering’s THIEVES OF WEIRDWOOD (Holt, 338 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12) is that it will delight and satiate those besotted with Harry Potter, Percy Jackson, Artemis Fowl, Miss Peregrine, the Spiderwicks. It boasts a familiar but enticing list of ingredients — an orphaned hero, plucky sidekicks, shape-shifting monsters, hidden worlds, magical peacekeepers, foul deeds, fateful destinies — whisked into a story that is fast-paced, funny and sometimes surprising. It comes to a satisfying conclusion, though with just enough loose ends, and an appended cliffhanger, to propel readers forward to the next installment, since being the first book in a series is arguably the single most essential part of the recipe, like sugar in a cookie.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Make the Zestiest Macaroni Salad
description: Macaroni salad with lemon and herbs, blueberry cobbler, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include macaroni salad with lemon and herbs (above), blueberry cobbler, and one-pot chicken and rice with ginger and cumin. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: America Is a Tinderbox
description: Scenes from a country in free fall.
content: The last two and a half months in America have felt like the opening montage in a dystopian film about a nation come undone. First the pandemic hit and hospitals in New York City were overwhelmed. The national economy froze and unemployment soared; one in four American workers has applied for unemployment benefits since March. Lines of cars stretched for miles at food banks. Heavily armed lockdown protesters demonstrated across the country; in Michigan, they forced the Capitol to close and legislators to cancel their session. Nationwide, at least 100,000 people died of a disease almost no one had heard of last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: The Rich Love India’s Lockdown. For the Poor It’s Another Story.
description: Estimates show the lockdown is pushing tens of millions of Indians below the poverty line.
content: I landed in Delhi on a work trip in mid-March and just over a week later, Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced what was soon recognized as the world’s strictest lockdown. He warned Indians to imagine “a sacrosanct line” around their homes, not to be breached for work or travel of any kind, not even a walk outdoors. Evoking the 18-day war described in the Mahabharata, an ancient Indian epic, Mr. Modi said it would take 21 days to win the war on the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How the Supreme Court Lets Cops Get Away With Murder
description: The courts protected police abuses for years before George Floyd’s death. It’s time to rethink “qualified immunity.”
content: A Minneapolis police officer, who was filmed kneeling on George Floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes until the life left his body, has been fired, arrested and charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. That is a step toward justice. Those who take a life should face a jury of their peers. But the rarity of the arrest, the fact that police officers who brutalize or even kill other people while wearing a badge so seldom end up facing any consequences is an ugly reminder of how unjust America’s legal system can be.
source.name: The New York Times

title: SpaceX Launch: Highlights From NASA Astronauts’ Trip to Orbit
description: Here’s what you need to know about Saturday’s second launch attempt of NASA astronauts in the Crew Dragon spacecraft.
content: The United States opened a new era of human space travel on Saturday as a private company for the first time launched astronauts into orbit, nearly a decade after the government retired the storied space shuttle program in the aftermath of national tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Threatens White House Protesters With ‘Vicious Dogs’ and ‘Ominous Weapons’
description: The president, before traveling to Florida to watch a rocket launch, also said that his base “loves the black people.” Hours later, intense protests erupted near the White House for a second night.
content: A day after claiming he didn’t mean to suggest that law enforcement officials should shoot people who were part of the unrest in Minnesota, President Trump said on Saturday that the Secret Service had been prepared to sic the “most vicious dogs” on protesters outside the White House gates on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles and Cayce Clifford
title: In Lockdown, a Neighborhood Opens Up
description: Grab a hyperlocal bakery loaf and a copy of the kids’ newspaper, and we can discuss over stoop cocktails.
content: The residents of Bernal Heights, a dense little neighborhood built around a grassy hill in the south of San Francisco, have been under lockdown a long time — since March 17, to be exact, when the city became among the first in the United States to shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Do Runners Need to Wear Masks?
description: Some people have taken to yelling (online and off) at people exercising without masks. But does it really matter?
content: Jane Rosen began yelling sometime in April. By May, it had become routine. The incidents usually occur near her minivan, which she parks alongside Central Park in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: In Some Nations, Coronavirus Is Only One of Many Outbreaks
description: In countries like Honduras, the virus has diverted resources from efforts to fight other serious diseases, straining weak public health systems, draining supplies and unraveling hard-won gains.
content: MEXICO CITY — A dengue epidemic ravaged Honduras last year, sickening over 100,000 people and leaving 180 dead. As this year began, officials braced for another surge in cases of the mosquito-borne disease and wondered how they would manage with their frail public health system and shortage of trained personnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
title: A Mile-Long Line for Free Food in Geneva, One of World’s Richest Cities
description: The Swiss city is best known for bankers, watchmakers and U.N. officials. But the virus has forced thousands from Geneva’s underclass to line up for hours for food aid.
content: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Matt Furber and Campbell Robertson
title: Appeals for Calm as Sprawling Protests Threaten to Spiral Out of Control
description: Escalating violence and destruction raised questions about whether a diverse, broadly decentralized protest movement was veering off track.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The nation was rocked again on Saturday as demonstrators clashed with police from outside the White House gates to the streets of more than three dozen besieged cities, as outrage over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis traversed a razor’s edge between protest and civic meltdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Twitter Had Been Drawing a Line for Months When Trump Crossed It
description: Inside the company, one faction wanted Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief, to take a hard line against the president’s tweets while another urged him to remain hands-off.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Jack Dorsey was up late Thursday at his home in San Francisco talking online with his executives when their conversation was interrupted: President Trump had just posted another inflammatory message on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Steven Lee Myers
title: China and India Brawl at 14,000 Feet Along the Border
description: As China projects its power across Asia, and along the disputed India-China border in the Himalayas, India is feeling surrounded. Both sides insist they don’t want a war, but thousands of troops have been sent.
content: NEW DELHI — High in the Himalayas, an enormous fistfight erupted in early May between the soldiers of China and India. Brawls at 14,000 feet along their inhospitable and disputed frontier are not terribly unusual, but what happened next was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Matt Furber and Campbell Robertson
title: Appeals for Calm as Sprawling Protests Threaten to Spiral Out of Control
description: Escalating violence and destruction raised questions about whether a diverse, broadly decentralized protest movement was veering off track.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The nation was rocked again on Saturday as demonstrators clashed with police from outside the White House gates to the streets of more than three dozen besieged cities, as outrage over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis traversed a razor’s edge between protest and civic meltdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Confrontational
description: Brian Thomas brings us an action-packed Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Brian Thomas is a regular contributor who almost always works with a theme; this is his second Saturday grid. It’s classic-feeling and smooth, with interesting cluing and fun entries — nothing super flashy, but sometimes that’s the point!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Simon
title: Is Pickleball the Perfect Pandemic Pastime?
description: Ellen DeGeneres recently declared herself among the intergenerational sport’s ardent enthusiasts.
content: When social distancing mandates struck Daytona Beach, Fla., in April, residents of Latitude Margaritaville (one of several “55 and better” communities inspired by the Jimmy Buffett song) quickly gathered the essentials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Are Virtual Tours Really Enough Before Renting a New Home?
description: Video tours have quickly become the standard way to see available apartments and houses. But not all videos are created equal.
content: Q: I need to move by July 1 and am looking for a rental in Manhattan, but I can only view apartments virtually. How can I get a sense of what an apartment really looks like from just videos and photographs? How does anyone move into an apartment without ever visiting it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Annexing the West Bank Is a Brazen Violation of International Law
description: It would also render the territory into a patchwork of simmering, unstable Palestinian areas, forever threatening a new intifada.
content: For his next act, after surviving a yearlong political struggle that he needed three national elections and a health crisis to overcome, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has announced that on July 1 he will start the process to annex Jewish settlements and the Jordan Valley in the West Bank, as he pledged to do in his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Hurd
title: Leaving the W.H.O. Shows Poor Leadership
description: America should be demanding answers, not retreating.
content: President Trump’s recent decision to terminate America’s role in the World Health Organization will have devastating effects on global health, and it will benefit the Chinese Communist Party. Throughout the Covid-19 crisis, the C.C.P. has pursued an aggressive messaging and disinformation campaign with twin goals: to restore its own image after a botched response to the pandemic and to sow discord among European nations about American commitment abroad. Moreover, leaving the W.H.O. sends the message that the world cannot count on the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Powell
title: Why Have One Pandemic Hobby When You Can Have 1,000 of Them?
description: My quest to try everything and oligarch nothing.
content: Over the past 60 days, I have not touched my stack of presidential biographies or baked a single loaf of sourdough bread. Nor have I acquired new muscle definition, signed up for a 12-week Russian course or embarked on the slow but fulfilling process of practicing a new hobby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cameron Silver
title: How to Organize Your Closet
description: You’re just a few steps away from a happier wardrobe.
content: Cameron Silver, the owner of Decades, a Los Angeles vintage haven known for high-end consignment, has years of experience organizing and preserving garments. Here, he shares advice for how to do it yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cuomo Focuses on Quelling Virus Hot Spots in N.Y.C. Before Reopening
description: As New York City looks to enter Phase 1 of reopening on June 8, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said officials were preparing hospitals for a potential uptick in coronavirus cases.
content: As New York City looks toward reopening on June 8, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Saturday that state officials were focusing on controlling hot spots in the city and preparing its hospitals to deal with a potential second spike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Sam Johnson, Congressman and Former P.O.W., Is Dead at 89
description: A much-decorated pilot held by the North Vietnamese for years, he would later criticize his fellow Republican Donald Trump for disparaging John McCain.
content: Sam Johnson, a former military pilot who suffered torture as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for nearly seven years, part of that time alongside John McCain, then came home to Texas to serve for 28 years in Congress, died on Wednesday in Plano, Texas. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: World Leaders, Pop Stars and Drag Queens to Headline Livestream for Gay Pride
description: Global Pride, a online event scheduled for June 27, will feature remarks by prime ministers and royalty as well as performances by international musical acts, according to organizers.
content: World leaders, human rights activists, international musical acts and drag queens will participate in a 24-hour online celebration of gay pride organized after the coronavirus pandemic forced the cancellation or postponement of hundreds of L.G.B.T.Q. pride events around the world, organizers announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Wealthy Fliers Worried About Coronavirus Turn to Private Jet Service
description: As business executives curtail their travel, jet service providers are shifting to meet the demand from people concerned about getting on a commercial flight.
content: Commercial air travel has plummeted in the pandemic, but interest in private jet service is surging, particularly among people who have not paid to fly privately before.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Now, the Sommelier Lifts His Mask to Sniff the Wine
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 30, 2020.
content: “Of course, there were many delivery companies, but it’s not the same, sitting on your sofa and having this ugly pizza.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Why Derek Chauvin Was Charged With Third-Degree Murder
description: A document by prosecutors details how Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, interacted with George Floyd before his death. Third-degree murder does not require an intent to kill.
content: The former Minneapolis police officer charged in the death of George Floyd held his knee to Mr. Floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes, including for two minutes and 53 seconds after Mr. Floyd became unresponsive, according to a document released by prosecutors on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iris van Herpen and Damien Jalet
title: Where Dance and Fashion Collide
description: A conversation between the designer Iris van Herpen and the choreographer Damien Jalet on the creative process.
content: This conversation is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Shum and Katie G. Nelson
title: Protesters Confront Police at Minneapolis Precinct
description: On the fourth night of unrest in Minneapolis, protesters expressed outrage at the police at the Fifth Precinct as the surrounding area turned into a smoky battleground.
content: On the fourth night of unrest in Minneapolis, protesters expressed outrage at the police at the Fifth Precinct as the surrounding area turned into a smoky battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Protests Flare in Brooklyn Over Floyd Death as de Blasio Appeals for Calm
description: Demonstrators stormed the perimeter of Barclays Center, hurling bottles and debris at police officers. The police responded with pepper spray and arrested more than 200 people.
content: [The latest: Protests Over George Floyd Death Reach Trump Tower and Across N.Y.C.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: How to Disinfect a Police Car in a Pandemic: Make It an Oven
description: The N.Y.P.D. and other departments were concerned about the spread of the coronavirus in vehicles. Ford’s answer is software to crank up the heat.
content: Over the last two months, law-enforcement agencies around the country have increasingly found themselves transporting people infected with the coronavirus, and facing the challenge of how to quickly and effectively sanitize their vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Amy Qin
title: In Hong Kong, Anxiety and Defiance Over Trump’s Move to Cut Ties
description: The reactions to President Trump’s decision fell along familiar political fault lines in a city wracked by nearly a year of protests.
content: HONG KONG — Hong Kong officials reacted with a mix of anxiety, resignation and defiance to President Trump’s announcement that the United States would end its special relationship with the city, reflecting the semiautonomous territory’s deep political divide over its relationship with mainland China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Azi Paybarah
title: Thousands Protest in N.Y.C., Reaching All 5 Boroughs and Trump Tower
description: In a third day of demonstrations over George Floyd’s death, protesters blocked traffic, set fire to police vehicles and scuffled with officers across the city.
content: Thousands of demonstrators protesting the death of George Floyd took to the streets of New York City for a third day on Saturday, blocking traffic, setting fire to police vehicles and scuffling with officers at simultaneous marches that raged through all five boroughs and briefly stopped outside Trump Tower in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: George Floyd Protests: A Timeline
description: Demonstrators in Minneapolis and across the country have poured into the streets since George Floyd died in police custody. Here’s how the protests have unfolded.
content: After the death of George Floyd on Monday, protests and unrest have rocked Minneapolis. Demonstrators vandalized property and targeted police cars. The police have used tear gas and fired rubber bullets into crowds.
source.name: The New York Times
